title: Cornus walteri
text:
Cornus walteri, also called Walter's dogwood, is a <a href="deciduous">deciduous</a> <a href="shrub">shrub</a> or small <a href="tree">tree</a> 8–16 m tall, native to eastern <a href="Asia">Asia</a> in <a href="Korea">Korea</a> and much of <a href="China">China</a> from <a href="Liaoning">Liaoning</a> to <a href="Yunnan">Yunnan</a>.
"Cornus walteri" has opposite, simple <a href="leaf">leaves</a>, 5–12 cm long. The <a href="flower">flower</a>s are produced in inflorescences 6–8 cm diameter, each flower individually small and whitish. The flowering is in spring, after it leafs out. The <a href="fruit">fruit</a> is a round, reddish-purple "<a href="drupe">drupaceous</a> <a href="Berry%20%28botany%29">berry</a>", 2.5-3.5 cm diameter.
It is closely related to the European <a href="common%20dogwood">common dogwood</a> ("C. sanguinea").
